patient_presentation.initial_description: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a sudden, severe headache that started 3 hours ago while exercising at the gym. He rates the pain as 10 out of 10 and says nothing like this has ever happened before.

critical.label: Life-Threatening
critical.reason: Subarachnoid hemorrhage has 50% mortality if untreated. Thunderclap headache requires emergent CT and, if negative, lumbar puncture. The Ottawa SAH Rule (age >=40, neck pain/stiffness, LOC, onset during exertion, thunderclap, limited neck flexion) has 100% sensitivity.

critical.label: Life-Threatening
critical.reason: Bacterial meningitis carries high mortality without prompt antibiotics. The classic triad (fever, neck stiffness, altered mental status) is present in only 44% of cases, but 95% have at least two of: fever, headache, neck stiffness, altered mental status.

actions.question: How quickly did the headache reach its worst?
actions.description: Determines headache tempo. Thunderclap onset (peak within seconds) is the hallmark of subarachnoid hemorrhage and other vascular emergencies.
actions.answer: It hit me like a bolt of lightning. One second I was fine, the next I had the worst pain of my life. It peaked within seconds.

potential_findings.description: Headache reaching maximum intensity within seconds, characteristic of vascular emergencies.
Progressive headache building over minutes to hours, more typical of primary headaches.

actions.question: What were you doing when the headache started?
actions.description: Identifies exertional triggers. Onset during Valsalva or physical exertion raises suspicion for aneurysmal rupture.
actions.answer: I was doing deadlifts at the gym. It hit right as I was straining on a heavy rep.

potential_findings.description: Headache triggered by strenuous activity or Valsalva maneuver, associated with aneurysmal rupture.

potential_findings.finding: Onset at rest or during routine activity
potential_findings.description: No exertional trigger identified; does not exclude vascular pathology.

actions.question: Is this the worst headache of your life?
actions.description: Screens for sentinel headache. A 'worst ever' headache in an adult mandates investigation for subarachnoid hemorrhage.
actions.answer: Absolutely. Nothing has ever come close to this. I thought I was dying.

potential_findings.description: Patient identifies this as unprecedentedly severe, a red flag for secondary causes.
Patient has experienced similar severity before, suggesting a recurrent primary headache.

actions.question: Do you have any neck pain or stiffness?
actions.description: Assesses for meningismus. Neck stiffness occurs in both subarachnoid hemorrhage (blood irritating meninges) and meningitis.
actions.answer: Yes, my neck is really stiff and painful, especially when I try to look down.

potential_findings.description: Meningismus suggesting meningeal irritation from blood or infection.
Absence of meningismus; reduces likelihood of meningeal pathology.

actions.question: Have you vomited?
actions.description: Evaluates for associated emesis. Vomiting occurs in SAH, migraine, meningitis, and raised intracranial pressure.
actions.answer: Yes, I vomited three times on the way here.

potential_findings.description: Multiple episodes of emesis accompanying headache onset.
Absence of emesis; less typical of acute intracranial pathology.

actions.question: Are you bothered by light?
actions.description: Assesses photophobia. A key migraine feature (LR+ 5.8 for migraine) but also seen in meningeal irritation from any cause.
actions.answer: Yes, the lights in here are really bothering me.

potential_findings.description: Light sensitivity indicating meningeal irritation or migraine pathophysiology.
Absence of light sensitivity; argues against migraine and meningeal irritation.

actions.question: Have you had any fever or chills?
actions.description: Screens for infectious etiology. Fever is present in 95% of bacterial meningitis; absence substantially reduces its likelihood.
actions.answer: No, I don't feel feverish at all. No chills either.

potential_findings.description: Febrile illness suggesting infectious or inflammatory etiology.
Afebrile state; substantially reduces probability of bacterial meningitis.

actions.question: Do you have a history of migraines or recurrent headaches?
actions.description: Establishes prior headache pattern. Absence of migraine history in a patient with first severe headache mandates exclusion of secondary causes.
actions.answer: No, I occasionally get a mild headache with stress, but nothing remotely like this.

potential_findings.description: Established migraine diagnosis with similar prior episodes.
First presentation of severe headache; raises concern for secondary causes.

actions.question: Did you lose consciousness or black out?
actions.description: Screens for syncope at headache onset. Transient loss of consciousness occurs in ~50% of aneurysmal SAH from acute intracranial pressure rise.
actions.answer: I think so. My gym partner said I went pale and slumped over for a few seconds before I came to.

potential_findings.description: Transient syncope at headache onset from acute intracranial pressure rise.
Patient remained alert throughout; does not exclude SAH.

actions.question: Any weakness, numbness, speech difficulty, or vision changes?
actions.description: Screens for focal neurological deficits suggesting structural intracranial pathology or migraine with aura.
actions.answer: No weakness or numbness. My vision seems normal, the light just hurts. Speech is fine.

potential_findings.description: Motor, sensory, visual or speech deficits localizing to a vascular territory.
Absence of lateralizing signs; does not exclude intracranial pathology.

actions.question: Have you been sick recently? Any contact with ill people?
actions.description: Screens for infectious exposure relevant to meningitis. Recent URI or sick contacts raise concern for meningococcal disease.
actions.answer: No, I've been completely healthy. Nobody around me has been sick.

potential_findings.description: Infectious prodrome or exposure raising suspicion for meningitis.
No infectious prodrome; reduces but does not exclude meningitis.

actions.question: Do you have high blood pressure or take any medications?
actions.description: Assesses cardiovascular risk factors. Hypertension is both a risk factor for SAH and the primary cause of hypertensive emergency.
actions.answer: My doctor mentioned my blood pressure was a bit high at my last checkup, but I'm not on any medications for it.

potential_findings.description: Known elevated blood pressure, a major risk factor for hemorrhagic stroke.
No vascular risk factors identified.

actions.question: Where is the headache located?
actions.description: Headache topography aids diagnosis. Occipital or diffuse headache favors SAH; unilateral temporal suggests migraine or GCA.
actions.answer: It's all over, but worst at the back of my head and down my neck.

potential_findings.description: Posterior and generalized distribution consistent with meningeal irritation.
Lateralized pain in the temporal region, classic for migraine or temporal arteritis.
Pressure-type pain encircling the head, characteristic of tension-type headache.

actions.question: Does the headache throb or is it more of a constant pressure?
actions.description: Headache quality differentiates primary headaches. Pulsating quality is a POUND criterion for migraine (LR+ for migraine).
actions.answer: It's a constant, severe pressure. It doesn't throb or pulse.

potential_findings.description: Pulsatile headache meeting a POUND criterion for migraine diagnosis.
Non-pulsatile headache; argues against migraine, consistent with tension-type or secondary causes.

actions.question: Check vital signs
actions.description: Blood pressure, heart rate, temperature, and oxygen saturation. Fever suggests infection; severe hypertension may indicate hypertensive emergency or reactive elevation.
actions.answer: BP 172/98 mmHg, HR 92 bpm, Temp 36.8°C (98.2°F), RR 18, SpO2 99%.

potential_findings.description: Moderate hypertension without fever. BP elevation may be reactive (pain, SAH) or chronic.
Fever present, suggesting infectious or inflammatory etiology.
Hypertensive crisis range with potential for end-organ damage.

actions.question: Assess nuchal rigidity
actions.description: Tests for meningismus by passively flexing the neck. Present in 70% of bacterial meningitis and in SAH from blood irritating the meninges.
actions.answer: Marked nuchal rigidity. Patient resists passive neck flexion and reports significant pain with attempted chin-to-chest movement.

potential_findings.description: Resistance to passive neck flexion indicating meningeal irritation.
No resistance to passive neck flexion; argues against meningeal irritation.

actions.question: Perform Kernig and Brudzinski signs
actions.description: Classical meningeal signs. Sensitivity is only 5-30% but specificity is 95%. Positive signs strongly suggest meningeal irritation.
actions.answer: Brudzinski sign positive: passive neck flexion causes involuntary hip and knee flexion. Kernig sign equivocal bilaterally.

potential_findings.description: Brudzinski or Kernig sign present; high specificity (95%) for meningeal pathology.
Both Kernig and Brudzinski negative. Low sensitivity (5-30%) means this does not exclude meningitis or SAH.

actions.question: Perform full neurological examination
actions.description: Comprehensive assessment of cranial nerves, motor, sensory, reflexes, and coordination. Focal findings localize pathology.
actions.answer: Cranial nerves II-XII intact. No motor or sensory deficits. Reflexes symmetric. Coordination normal. No pronator drift.

potential_findings.description: Cranial nerve palsy, hemiparesis, or other lateralizing signs localizing to a vascular territory.
No lateralizing deficits identified; does not exclude intracranial pathology.

actions.question: Assess mental status and level of consciousness
actions.description: Evaluates for altered sensorium. Altered mental status is a component of the meningitis triad and indicates raised intracranial pressure.
actions.answer: GCS 15. Alert and oriented to person, place, time, and situation. Slightly irritable but coherent and appropriate.

potential_findings.description: Confusion, drowsiness, or disorientation suggesting raised ICP or encephalopathy.
Alert and fully oriented; reduces likelihood of meningitis and severe SAH.

actions.question: Palpate temporal arteries
actions.description: Assesses for temporal artery tenderness, beading, prominence, or absent pulse—signs of giant cell arteritis.
actions.answer: Temporal arteries are soft, pulsatile bilaterally, and non-tender. No beading or prominence noted.

potential_findings.description: Tenderness, beading, prominence, or absent pulse in the temporal arteries (LR+ 2.6-4.6 for GCA).
No tenderness or structural abnormality; absence modestly reduces GCA likelihood (LR- 0.53).

actions.question: Perform fundoscopic examination
actions.description: Direct ophthalmoscopy evaluates for papilledema (raised ICP), subhyaloid hemorrhage (SAH), or hypertensive retinopathy.
actions.answer: No papilledema. A small subhyaloid hemorrhage is noted in the left eye. No hypertensive retinopathy changes.

potential_findings.description: Preretinal hemorrhage from acute intracranial pressure rise; occurs in 20-40% of SAH.
Bilateral optic disc swelling indicating raised intracranial pressure.
No papilledema, hemorrhage, or vascular changes identified.

actions.question: Order CT Head non-contrast
actions.description: First-line imaging for acute headache. CT within 6 hours of onset has 98.7% sensitivity for SAH. Identifies hemorrhage, mass, and hydrocephalus.
actions.answer: Hyperdense material in the basal cisterns, sylvian fissures, and interhemispheric fissure consistent with acute subarachnoid hemorrhage. No hydrocephalus. No intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

potential_findings.description: Hyperdense blood in the subarachnoid space; essentially diagnostic of SAH.
No hemorrhage or mass. CT sensitivity decreases with time; LP may still be needed if clinical suspicion is high.

actions.question: Order CT Angiography of head and neck
actions.description: Identifies aneurysms, arterial dissection, and vascular malformations. Sensitivity >95% for aneurysms >3mm.
actions.answer: 5mm saccular aneurysm at the anterior communicating artery with adjacent hemorrhage. No additional aneurysms. No dissection.

potential_findings.description: Saccular aneurysm at a typical location with surrounding hemorrhage; confirms aneurysmal SAH.
No aneurysm, dissection, or vascular malformation identified.

actions.question: Perform lumbar puncture
actions.description: Measures opening pressure and CSF composition. Required if CT is negative but SAH suspicion remains. Xanthochromia confirms SAH; pleocytosis suggests meningitis.
actions.answer: Opening pressure elevated at 28 cm H2O. CSF appears xanthochromic. RBC 12,500 (non-diminishing in sequential tubes). WBC 18. Protein mildly elevated. Glucose normal. Gram stain negative.

potential_findings.description: Yellow discoloration of CSF with non-diminishing red cells across tubes; confirms subarachnoid blood.
Elevated WBC with neutrophil predominance, low glucose, elevated protein consistent with bacterial meningitis.
Normal opening pressure, clear CSF, no cells, normal chemistry.

actions.question: Order ECG
actions.description: Screens for cardiac arrhythmias and neurogenic cardiac changes. SAH can cause diffuse T-wave inversions and QTc prolongation.
actions.answer: Sinus tachycardia at 94 bpm. Diffuse deep T-wave inversions across precordial leads. QTc prolonged at 480ms. No ST elevation.

potential_findings.description: Diffuse T-wave inversions and QTc prolongation; classic neurogenic cardiac changes seen in SAH.
Normal sinus rhythm without ST-T changes or conduction abnormalities.

actions.question: Order CBC and Basic Metabolic Panel
actions.description: Baseline labs. Leukocytosis may indicate infection or stress response. Electrolyte derangements can cause headache.
actions.answer: WBC 11.8 (mildly elevated), Hgb 14.5, Plt 220. Na 139, K 4.0, Cr 1.0, Glucose 142 (mildly elevated). Coagulation studies normal.

potential_findings.description: Non-specific stress response; mild WBC elevation does not distinguish between causes.
WBC >15,000 suggesting significant infectious or inflammatory process.
All values within reference ranges.

actions.question: Order ESR and CRP
actions.description: Inflammatory markers. ESR >50 has sensitivity of 87% for GCA (negative LR 0.27). Normal values substantially reduce GCA probability.
actions.answer: ESR 12 mm/hr (normal, reference <20). CRP 0.4 mg/dL (normal, reference <1.0).

potential_findings.description: ESR >50 and elevated CRP strongly suggestive of inflammatory vasculitis (GCA LR+ 3.1 for ESR >100).
Normal ESR and CRP substantially reduce probability of GCA (negative LR 0.2-0.27).

key_findings: Worst headache of life in a patient without migraine history
Transient loss of consciousness at onset
Nuchal rigidity and positive Brudzinski sign
CT showing subarachnoid blood in basal cisterns
Neurogenic ECG changes (T-wave inversions, prolonged QTc)
sah.clinical_pearl: The Ottawa SAH Rule (age >=40, neck pain/stiffness, witnessed LOC, onset during exertion, thunderclap onset, limited neck flexion) has 100% sensitivity for SAH. CT within 6 hours has 98.7% sensitivity; if negative, lumbar puncture with xanthochromia testing is required. Never dismiss a first or worst headache as migraine without excluding SAH.

would_show: Inflammatory CSF (elevated WBC, low glucose, elevated protein)
meningitis.clinical_pearl: The classic triad of fever, neck stiffness, and altered mental status is present in only 44% of bacterial meningitis cases, but 95% have at least two of: fever, headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. The absence of all three effectively rules out meningitis.
